Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Maass Forms, Modular Forms, and Applicati
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports research at the intersection of number theory, combinatorics, and Lie theory. In particular, the P.I. seeks to determine more precise relationships and interplay between weak Maass forms and their generalizations, (non-holomorphic) Jacobi forms, and combinatorial q-hypergeometric series. The major project objectives include a study of quantum modular forms, vertex operator algebra trace functions and graded dimensions, and the automorphic properties of combinatorial q-series. The P.I. will additionally integrate a number of educational and outreach programs at all levels into the award objectives. Namely, the P.I. has begun a collaboration with the New Haven Public Schools, and will continue to develop a mathematics enrichment program for elementary and middle school students. The P.I. will also act as faculty advisor to the Yale University-New Haven chapter of MATHCOUNTS Outreach, an undergraduate arm of the national organization which promotes mathematics in New Haven Public Schools. The P.I. also seeks to enhance research and educational opportunities for graduate students, undergraduate students, and postdoctoral fellows, including women and girls in mathematics at all levels, through research collaboration, mentoring, and outreach programs.

Number theory is one of the oldest branches of mathematics, and continues to be a field of extensive and active research today. Modular forms have played many fundamental roles; they are central to the proof of Fermat's Last Theorem, the Langlands program, the Riemann hypothesis, and the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer conjecture, for example, and yield applications in combinatorics, cryptography, mathematical physics, and many other areas. The P.I. will study natural relatives of modular forms, namely weak Maass forms and their generalizations. While recent developments have been made, a comprehensive theory is lacking. The proposed research seeks to contribute to the understanding of the roles of these functions not only within number theory and modular forms, but also combinatorics and Lie theory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this award lie at the intersection of number theory, combinatorics, and representation theory, and integrate mathematical research, education, and outreach.  To this end, the P.I. authored over 25 publications under this award, including: one ~400 page research-level book published by the American Mathematical Society which won the 2018 American Publisher's Association PROSE Award for Best Scholarly Book in Mathematics; 18 research articles in journals including J. Reine Angew. Math. (Crelle's J.), Advances in Math.,  J. Math. Phys., Res. Number Theory, J. Number Theory, Ann. Inst. Fourier  (Grenoble), and more; and 7 mathematical expository articles in journals including Notices of the AMS, J. Number Theory, and more.  

In particular, the products of this award surround the problem of determining precise relationships and interplay between harmonic Maass forms and related functions, mock modular forms, (non-holomorphic) Jacobi forms, quantum modular forms and combinatorial q-hypergeometric series in number theory, as well as applications of these subjects to combinatorics, representation theory and mathematical physics.

The award outcomes also integrate a number of  educational and outreach programs and include various broader impacts.  In particular, the P.I. is dedicated to mentoring and advising undergraduate research, and via funding provided by this award, the P.I. advised five groups of undergraduate research students in 2014, 2015, 2017 and 2018, leading to 5 co-authored student publications in professional mathematics journals.  Related, the P.I. co-founded the SUMRY Program at Yale University,  a larger scale REU-like undergraduate mathematics research program which continues to thrive.  The P.I. also developed a math enrichment program "EYE on Mathematics" at the K-8 public school Edgewood in New Haven, CT, in partnership with the principal and math faculty.  Regarding women in mathematics, the P.I. was a project leader at the Women in Numbers 4 Workshop at BIRS, Banff in 2017, and was a co-project leader to an all-women research group an American Institute of Mathematics Square Workshop in 2015.  Since 2015, the P.I. has also served as an AWM Mentor to junior women in math.

The research award outcomes mentioned above study natural relatives of modular forms, namely harmonic Maass forms, mock modular forms, and related functions. The P.I.'s research contributes to the development of a more comprehensive theory of harmonic Maass forms, and to the understanding of the roles of these functions not only within number theory and modular forms, but also to other areas.
